CreateKxChangeset.name: CreateKxChangeset
CreateKxChangeset.documentation: Creates a changeset for a kdb database. A changeset allows you to add and delete existing files by using an ordered list of change requests.

CreateKxDatabase.name: CreateKxDatabase
CreateKxDatabase.documentation: Creates a new kdb database in the environment.

CreateKxEnvironment.name: CreateKxEnvironment
CreateKxEnvironment.documentation: Creates a managed kdb environment for the account.

CreateKxUser.name: CreateKxUser
CreateKxUser.documentation: Creates a user in FinSpace kdb environment with an associated IAM role.

DeleteKxDatabase.name: DeleteKxDatabase
DeleteKxDatabase.documentation: Deletes the specified database and all of its associated data. This action is irreversible. You must copy any data out of the database before deleting it if the data is to be retained.

DeleteKxEnvironment.name: DeleteKxEnvironment
DeleteKxEnvironment.documentation: Deletes the kdb environment. This action is irreversible. Deleting a kdb environment will remove all the associated data and any services running in it.

DeleteKxUser.name: DeleteKxUser
DeleteKxUser.documentation: Deletes a user in the specified kdb environment.

GetKxConnectionString.name: GetKxConnectionString
GetKxConnectionString.documentation: Retrieves a connection string for a user to connect to a kdb cluster. You must call this API using the same role that you have defined while creating a user.

GetKxDatabase.name: GetKxDatabase
GetKxDatabase.documentation: Returns database information for the specified environment ID.

GetKxEnvironment.name: GetKxEnvironment
GetKxEnvironment.documentation: Retrieves all the information for the specified kdb environment.

GetKxUser.name: GetKxUser
GetKxUser.documentation: Retrieves information about the specified kdb user.

ListEnvironments.name: ListEnvironments
ListEnvironments.documentation: A list of all of your FinSpace environments.

ListKxChangesets.name: ListKxChangesets
ListKxChangesets.documentation: Returns a list of all the changesets for a database.

ListKxClusterNodes.name: ListKxClusterNodes
ListKxClusterNodes.documentation: Lists all the nodes in a kdb cluster.

ListKxDatabases.name: ListKxDatabases
ListKxDatabases.documentation: Returns a list of all the databases in the kdb environment.

ListKxEnvironments.name: ListKxEnvironments
ListKxEnvironments.documentation: Returns a list of kdb environments created in an account.

ListKxUsers.name: ListKxUsers
ListKxUsers.documentation: Lists all the users in a kdb environment.

ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource
ListTagsForResource.documentation: A list of all tags for a resource.

TagResource.name: TagResource
TagResource.documentation: Adds metadata tags to a FinSpace resource.

UntagResource.name: UntagResource
UntagResource.documentation: Removes metadata tags from a FinSpace resource.

UpdateKxClusterCodeConfiguration.name: UpdateKxClusterCodeConfiguration
UpdateKxClusterCodeConfiguration.documentation: Allows you to update code configuration on a running cluster. By using this API you can update the code, the initialization script path, and the command line arguments for a specific cluster. The configuration that you want to update will override any existing configurations on the cluster.

UpdateKxClusterDatabases.name: UpdateKxClusterDatabases
UpdateKxClusterDatabases.documentation:
Updates the databases mounted on a kdb cluster, which includes the changesetId and all the dbPaths to be cached. This API does not allow you to change a database name or add a database if you created a cluster without one.

Using this API you can point a cluster to a different changeset and modify a list of partitions being cached.

UpdateKxDatabase.name: UpdateKxDatabase
UpdateKxDatabase.documentation: Updates information for the given kdb database.

UpdateKxEnvironment.name: UpdateKxEnvironment
UpdateKxEnvironment.documentation: Updates information for the given kdb environment.

UpdateKxEnvironmentNetwork.name: UpdateKxEnvironmentNetwork
UpdateKxEnvironmentNetwork.documentation:
Updates environment network to connect to your internal network by using a transit gateway. This API supports request to create a transit gateway attachment from FinSpace VPC to your transit gateway ID and create a custom Route-53 outbound resolvers.

Once you send a request to update a network, you cannot change it again. Network update might require termination of any clusters that are running in the existing network.

UpdateKxUser.name: UpdateKxUser
UpdateKxUser.documentation: Updates the user details. You can only update the IAM role associated with a user.

AccessDeniedException.documentation: You do not have sufficient access to perform this action.

minNodeCount.documentation: The lowest number of nodes to scale. This value must be at least 1 and less than the maxNodeCount. If the nodes in a cluster belong to multiple availability zones, then minNodeCount must be at least 3.

maxNodeCount.documentation: The highest number of nodes to scale. This value cannot be greater than 5.

autoScalingMetric.documentation: The metric your cluster will track in order to scale in and out. For example, CPU_UTILIZATION_PERCENTAGE is the average CPU usage across all the nodes in a cluster.

metricTarget.documentation: The desired value of the chosen autoScalingMetric. When the metric drops below this value, the cluster will scale in. When the metric goes above this value, the cluster will scale out. You can set the target value between 1 and 100 percent.

scaleInCooldownSeconds.documentation: The duration in seconds that FinSpace will wait after a scale in event before initiating another scaling event.

scaleOutCooldownSeconds.documentation: The duration in seconds that FinSpace will wait after a scale out event before initiating another scaling event.

AutoScalingConfiguration.documentation: The configuration based on which FinSpace will scale in or scale out nodes in your cluster.

nodeType.documentation:
The type that determines the hardware of the host computer used for your cluster instance. Each node type offers different memory and storage capabilities. Choose a node type based on the requirements of the application or software that you plan to run on your instance.

You can only specify one of the following values:

  • kx.s.large – The node type with a configuration of 12 GiB memory and 2 vCPUs.

  • kx.s.xlarge – The node type with a configuration of 27 GiB memory and 4 vCPUs.

  • kx.s.2xlarge – The node type with a configuration of 54 GiB memory and 8 vCPUs.

  • kx.s.4xlarge – The node type with a configuration of 108 GiB memory and 16 vCPUs.

  • kx.s.8xlarge – The node type with a configuration of 216 GiB memory and 32 vCPUs.

  • kx.s.16xlarge – The node type with a configuration of 432 GiB memory and 64 vCPUs.

  • kx.s.32xlarge – The node type with a configuration of 864 GiB memory and 128 vCPUs.

nodeCount.documentation: The number of instances running in a cluster.

CapacityConfiguration.documentation: A structure for the metadata of a cluster. It includes information like the CPUs needed, memory of instances, and number of instances.

changeType.documentation:
Defines the type of change request. A changeType can have the following values:

  • PUT – Adds or updates files in a database.

  • DELETE – Deletes files in a database.

s3Path.documentation: Defines the S3 path of the source file that is required to add or update files in a database.

dbPath.documentation: Defines the path within the database directory.

s3Bucket.documentation: A unique name for the S3 bucket.

s3Key.documentation: The full S3 path (excluding bucket) to the .zip file. This file contains the code that is loaded onto the cluster when it's started.

CodeConfiguration.documentation: The structure of the customer code available within the running cluster.

ConflictException.documentation: There was a conflict with this action, and it could not be completed.

name.documentation: The name of the FinSpace environment to be created.

description.documentation: The description of the FinSpace environment to be created.

kmsKeyId.documentation: The KMS key id to encrypt your data in the FinSpace environment.

federationMode.documentation:
Authentication mode for the environment.

  • FEDERATED - Users access FinSpace through Single Sign On (SSO) via your Identity provider.

  • LOCAL - Users access FinSpace via email and password managed within the FinSpace environment.

federationParameters.documentation: Configuration information when authentication mode is FEDERATED.

dataBundles.documentation:
The list of Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of the data bundles to install. Currently supported data bundle ARNs:

  • arn:aws:finspace:${Region}::data-bundle/capital-markets-sample - Contains sample Capital Markets datasets, categories and controlled vocabularies.

  • arn:aws:finspace:${Region}::data-bundle/taq (default) - Contains trades and quotes data in addition to sample Capital Markets data.

environmentId.documentation: The unique identifier for FinSpace environment that you created.

environmentArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the FinSpace environment that you created.

environmentUrl.documentation: The sign-in URL for the web application of the FinSpace environment you created.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier of the kdb environment.

changeRequests.documentation:
A list of change request objects that are run in order. A change request object consists of changeType , s3Path, and a dbPath. A changeType can has the following values:

  • PUT – Adds or updates files in a database.

  • DELETE – Deletes files in a database.

All the change requests require a mandatory dbPath attribute that defines the path within the database directory. The s3Path attribute defines the s3 source file path and is required for a PUT change type.

Here is an example of how you can use the change request object:

[ { "changeType": "PUT", "s3Path":"s3://bucket/db/2020.01.02/", "dbPath":"/2020.01.02/"}, { "changeType": "PUT", "s3Path":"s3://bucket/db/sym", "dbPath":"/"}, { "changeType": "DELETE", "dbPath": "/2020.01.01/"} ]

In this example, the first request with PUT change type allows you to add files in the given s3Path under the 2020.01.02 partition of the database. The second request with PUT change type allows you to add a single sym file at database root location. The last request with DELETE change type allows you to delete the files under the 2020.01.01 partition of the database.

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the changeset was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the changeset was updated in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

status.documentation:
Status of the changeset creation process.

  • Pending – Changeset creation is pending.

  • Processing – Changeset creation is running.

  • Failed – Changeset creation has failed.

  • Complete – Changeset creation has succeeded.

errorInfo.documentation: The details of the error that you receive when creating a changeset. It consists of the type of error and the error message.

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

clusterName.documentation: A unique name for the cluster that you want to create.

clusterType.documentation:
Specifies the type of KDB database that is being created. The following types are available:

  • HDB – A Historical Database. The data is only accessible with read-only permissions from one of the FinSpace managed kdb databases mounted to the cluster.

  • RDB – A Realtime Database. This type of database captures all the data from a ticker plant and stores it in memory until the end of day, after which it writes all of its data to a disk and reloads the HDB. This cluster type requires local storage for temporary storage of data during the savedown process. If you specify this field in your request, you must provide the savedownStorageConfiguration parameter.

  • GATEWAY – A gateway cluster allows you to access data across processes in kdb systems. It allows you to create your own routing logic using the initialization scripts and custom code. This type of cluster does not require a writable local storage.

databases.documentation: A list of databases that will be available for querying.

cacheStorageConfigurations.documentation: The configurations for a read only cache storage associated with a cluster. This cache will be stored as an FSx Lustre that reads from the S3 store.

autoScalingConfiguration.documentation: The configuration based on which FinSpace will scale in or scale out nodes in your cluster.

capacityConfiguration.documentation: A structure for the metadata of a cluster. It includes information like the CPUs needed, memory of instances, and number of instances.

releaseLabel.documentation: The version of FinSpace managed kdb to run.

vpcConfiguration.documentation: Configuration details about the network where the Privatelink endpoint of the cluster resides.

initializationScript.documentation: Specifies a Q program that will be run at launch of a cluster. It is a relative path within .zip file that contains the custom code, which will be loaded on the cluster. It must include the file name itself. For example, somedir/init.q.

commandLineArguments.documentation: Defines the key-value pairs to make them available inside the cluster.

code.documentation: The details of the custom code that you want to use inside a cluster when analyzing a data. It consists of the S3 source bucket, location, S3 object version, and the relative path from where the custom code is loaded into the cluster.

executionRole.documentation: An IAM role that defines a set of permissions associated with a cluster. These permissions are assumed when a cluster attempts to access another cluster.

savedownStorageConfiguration.documentation: The size and type of the temporary storage that is used to hold data during the savedown process. This parameter is required when you choose clusterType as RDB. All the data written to this storage space is lost when the cluster node is restarted.

azMode.documentation:
The number of availability zones you want to assign per cluster. This can be one of the following

  • SINGLE – Assigns one availability zone per cluster.

  • MULTI – Assigns all the availability zones per cluster.

availabilityZoneId.documentation: The availability zone identifiers for the requested regions.

tags.documentation: A list of key-value pairs to label the cluster. You can add up to 50 tags to a cluster.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

status.documentation:
The status of cluster creation.

  • PENDING – The cluster is pending creation.

  • CREATING – The cluster creation process is in progress.

  • CREATE_FAILED – The cluster creation process has failed.

  • RUNNING – The cluster creation process is running.

  • UPDATING – The cluster is in the process of being updated.

  • DELETING – The cluster is in the process of being deleted.

  • DELETED – The cluster has been deleted.

  • DELETE_FAILED – The cluster failed to delete.

statusReason.documentation: The error message when a failed state occurs.

clusterType.documentation:
Specifies the type of KDB database that is being created. The following types are available:

  • HDB – A Historical Database. The data is only accessible with read-only permissions from one of the FinSpace managed kdb databases mounted to the cluster.

  • RDB – A Realtime Database. This type of database captures all the data from a ticker plant and stores it in memory until the end of day, after which it writes all of its data to a disk and reloads the HDB. This cluster type requires local storage for temporary storage of data during the savedown process. If you specify this field in your request, you must provide the savedownStorageConfiguration parameter.

  • GATEWAY – A gateway cluster allows you to access data across processes in kdb systems. It allows you to create your own routing logic using the initialization scripts and custom code. This type of cluster does not require a writable local storage.

databases.documentation: A list of databases that will be available for querying.

cacheStorageConfigurations.documentation: The configurations for a read only cache storage associated with a cluster. This cache will be stored as an FSx Lustre that reads from the S3 store.

vpcConfiguration.documentation: Configuration details about the network where the Privatelink endpoint of the cluster resides.

code.documentation: The details of the custom code that you want to use inside a cluster when analyzing a data. It consists of the S3 source bucket, location, S3 object version, and the relative path from where the custom code is loaded into the cluster.

executionRole.documentation: An IAM role that defines a set of permissions associated with a cluster. These permissions are assumed when a cluster attempts to access another cluster.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The last time that the cluster was modified. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

savedownStorageConfiguration.documentation: The size and type of the temporary storage that is used to hold data during the savedown process. This parameter is required when you choose clusterType as RDB. All the data written to this storage space is lost when the cluster node is restarted.

azMode.documentation:
The number of availability zones you want to assign per cluster. This can be one of the following

  • SINGLE – Assigns one availability zone per cluster.

  • MULTI – Assigns all the availability zones per cluster.

availabilityZoneId.documentation: The availability zone identifiers for the requested regions.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the cluster was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

tags.documentation: A list of key-value pairs to label the kdb database. You can add up to 50 tags to your kdb database

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

creationTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was created in FinSpace.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment where you want to create a user.

iamRole.documentation: The IAM role ARN that will be associated with the user.

tags.documentation: A list of key-value pairs to label the user. You can add up to 50 tags to a user.

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

userArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see IAM Identifiers in the IAM User Guide.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

iamRole.documentation: The IAM role ARN that will be associated with the user.

customDNSServerIP.documentation: The IP address of the DNS server.

CustomDNSServer.documentation: A list of DNS server name and server IP. This is used to set up Route-53 outbound resolvers.

DataBundleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the data bundle.

environmentId.documentation: The identifier for the FinSpace environment.
A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

clusterName.documentation: The name of the cluster that you want to delete.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

databaseName.documentation: The name of the kdb database that you want to delete.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

userName.documentation: A unique identifier for the user that you want to delete.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.
The identifier of the FinSpace environment.

awsAccountId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account in which the FinSpace environment is created.

status.documentation: The current status of creation of the FinSpace environment.

environmentUrl.documentation: The sign-in URL for the web application of your FinSpace environment.

environmentArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of your FinSpace environment.

sageMakerStudioDomainUrl.documentation: The URL of the integrated FinSpace notebook environment in your web application.

kmsKeyId.documentation: The KMS key id used to encrypt in the FinSpace environment.

dedicatedServiceAccountId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the dedicated service account associated with your FinSpace environment.

federationParameters.documentation: Configuration information when authentication mode is FEDERATED.

enum: The inputs to this request are invalid.
Missing required permission to perform this request.
One or more inputs to this request were not found.
The system temporarily lacks sufficient resources to process the request.
A user recoverable error has occurred

errorMessage.documentation: Specifies the error message that appears if a flow fails.

ErrorInfo.documentation: Provides details in the event of a failed flow, including the error type and the related error message.

samlMetadataURL.documentation: Provide the metadata URL from your SAML 2.0 compliant identity provider (IdP).

applicationCallBackURL.documentation: The redirect or sign-in URL that should be entered into the SAML 2.0 compliant identity provider configuration (IdP).

federationURN.documentation: The Uniform Resource Name (URN). Also referred as Service Provider URN or Audience URI or Service Provider Entity ID.

attributeMap.documentation: SAML attribute name and value. The name must always be Email and the value should be set to the attribute definition in which user email is set. For example, name would be Email and value http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress. Please check your SAML 2.0 compliant identity provider (IdP) documentation for details.

FederationParameters.documentation: Configuration information when authentication mode is FEDERATED.

environmentId.documentation: The identifier of the FinSpace environment.
A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

changesetId.documentation: A unique identifier of the changeset for which you want to retrieve data.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

changeRequests.documentation: A list of change request objects that are run in order.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the changeset was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

activeFromTimestamp.documentation: Beginning time from which the changeset is active. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the changeset was updated in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

status.documentation:
Status of the changeset creation process.

  • Pending – Changeset creation is pending.

  • Processing – Changeset creation is running.

  • Failed – Changeset creation has failed.

  • Complete – Changeset creation has succeeded.

errorInfo.documentation: Provides details in the event of a failed flow, including the error type and the related error message.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

clusterName.documentation: The name of the cluster that you want to retrieve.

status.documentation:
The status of cluster creation.

  • PENDING – The cluster is pending creation.

  • CREATING – The cluster creation process is in progress.

  • CREATE_FAILED – The cluster creation process has failed.

  • RUNNING – The cluster creation process is running.

  • UPDATING – The cluster is in the process of being updated.

  • DELETING – The cluster is in the process of being deleted.

  • DELETED – The cluster has been deleted.

  • DELETE_FAILED – The cluster failed to delete.

statusReason.documentation: The error message when a failed state occurs.

clusterType.documentation:
Specifies the type of KDB database that is being created. The following types are available:

  • HDB – A Historical Database. The data is only accessible with read-only permissions from one of the FinSpace managed kdb databases mounted to the cluster.

  • RDB – A Realtime Database. This type of database captures all the data from a ticker plant and stores it in memory until the end of day, after which it writes all of its data to a disk and reloads the HDB. This cluster type requires local storage for temporary storage of data during the savedown process. If you specify this field in your request, you must provide the savedownStorageConfiguration parameter.

  • GATEWAY – A gateway cluster allows you to access data across processes in kdb systems. It allows you to create your own routing logic using the initialization scripts and custom code. This type of cluster does not require a writable local storage.

The number of availability zones you want to assign per cluster. This can be one of the following

  • SINGLE – Assigns one availability zone per cluster.

  • MULTI – Assigns all the availability zones per cluster.

userArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see IAM Identifiers in the IAM User Guide.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

signedConnectionString.documentation: The signed connection string that you can use to connect to clusters.

databaseName.documentation: The name of the kdb database for which the information is retrieved.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the database is created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The last time that the database was modified. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

numBytes.documentation: The total number of bytes in the database.

numChangesets.documentation: The total number of changesets in the database.

numFiles.documentation: The total number of files in the database.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.
A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

awsAccountId.documentation: The unique identifier of the AWS account that is used to create the kdb environment.

errorMessage.documentation: Specifies the error message that appears if a flow fails.

kmsKeyId.documentation: The KMS key ID to encrypt your data in the FinSpace environment.

dedicatedServiceAccountId.documentation: A unique identifier for the AWS environment infrastructure account.

customDNSConfiguration.documentation: A list of DNS server name and server IP. This is used to set up Route-53 outbound resolvers.

creationTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was created in FinSpace.

updateTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was updated.

availabilityZoneIds.documentation: The identifier of the availability zones where subnets for the environment are created.

certificateAuthorityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the certificate authority of the kdb environment.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

userArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see IAM Identifiers in the IAM User Guide.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

iamRole.documentation: The IAM role ARN that is associated with the user.

type.documentation: The ICMP type. A value of -1 means all types.

code.documentation: The ICMP code. A value of -1 means all codes for the specified ICMP type.

IcmpTypeCode.documentation: Defines the ICMP protocol that consists of the ICMP type and code.

InternalServerException.documentation: The request processing has failed because of an unknown error, exception or failure.

InvalidRequestException.documentation: The request is invalid. Something is wrong with the input to the request.

type.documentation:
The type of cache storage. The valid values are:

  • CACHE_1000 – This type provides at least 1000 MB/s disk access throughput.

  • CACHE_250 – This type provides at least 250 MB/s disk access throughput.

  • CACHE_12 – This type provides at least 12 MB/s disk access throughput.

For cache type CACHE_1000 and CACHE_250 you can select cache size as 1200 GB or increments of 2400 GB. For cache type CACHE_12 you can select the cache size in increments of 6000 GB.

KxCacheStorageConfiguration.documentation: The configuration for read only disk cache associated with a cluster.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the changeset was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

activeFromTimestamp.documentation: Beginning time from which the changeset is active. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the changeset was modified. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

status.documentation:
Status of the changeset.

  • Pending – Changeset creation is pending.

  • Processing – Changeset creation is running.

  • Failed – Changeset creation has failed.

  • Complete – Changeset creation has succeeded.

The status of a cluster.

  • PENDING – The cluster is pending creation.

  • CREATING –The cluster creation process is in progress.

  • CREATE_FAILED– The cluster creation process has failed.

  • RUNNING – The cluster creation process is running.

  • UPDATING – The cluster is in the process of being updated.

  • DELETING – The cluster is in the process of being deleted.

  • DELETED – The cluster has been deleted.

  • DELETE_FAILED – The cluster failed to delete.

statusReason.documentation: The error message when a failed state occurs.

clusterType.documentation:
Specifies the type of KDB database that is being created. The following types are available:

  • HDB – A Historical Database. The data is only accessible with read-only permissions from one of the FinSpace managed kdb databases mounted to the cluster.

  • RDB – A Realtime Database. This type of database captures all the data from a ticker plant and stores it in memory until the end of day, after which it writes all of its data to a disk and reloads the HDB. This cluster type requires local storage for temporary storage of data during the savedown process. If you specify this field in your request, you must provide the savedownStorageConfiguration parameter.

  • GATEWAY – A gateway cluster allows you to access data across processes in kdb systems. It allows you to create your own routing logic using the initialization scripts and custom code. This type of cluster does not require a writable local storage.

releaseLabel.documentation: A version of the FinSpace managed kdb to run.

initializationScript.documentation: Specifies a Q program that will be run at launch of a cluster. It is a relative path within .zip file that contains the custom code, which will be loaded on the cluster. It must include the file name itself. For example, somedir/init.q.

executionRole.documentation: An IAM role that defines a set of permissions associated with a cluster. These permissions are assumed when a cluster attempts to access another cluster.

azMode.documentation:
The number of availability zones assigned per cluster. This can be one of the following:

  • SINGLE – Assigns one availability zone per cluster.

  • MULTI – Assigns all the availability zones per cluster.

availabilityZoneId.documentation: The availability zone identifiers for the requested regions.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The last time that the cluster was modified. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the cluster was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

deploymentStrategy.documentation:
The type of deployment that you want on a cluster.

  • ROLLING – This options updates the cluster by stopping the exiting q process and starting a new q process with updated configuration.

  • FORCE – This option updates the cluster by immediately stopping all the running processes before starting up new ones with the updated configuration.

KxClusterCodeDeploymentConfiguration.documentation: The configuration that allows you to choose how you want to update code on a cluster. Depending on the option you choose, you can reduce the time it takes to update the cluster.

KxCommandLineArgument.documentation: Defines the key-value pairs to make them available inside the cluster.

cacheType.documentation:
The type of disk cache. This parameter is used to map the database path to cache storage. The valid values are:

  • CACHE_1000 – This type provides at least 1000 MB/s disk access throughput.

dbPaths.documentation: Specifies the portions of database that will be loaded into the cache for access.

KxDatabaseCacheConfiguration.documentation: The structure of database cache configuration that is used for mapping database paths to cache types in clusters.

databaseName.documentation: The name of the kdb database. When this parameter is specified in the structure, S3 with the whole database is included by default.

cacheConfigurations.documentation: Configuration details for the disk cache used to increase performance reading from a kdb database mounted to the cluster.

changesetId.documentation: A unique identifier of the changeset that is associated with the cluster.

KxDatabaseConfiguration.documentation: The configuration of data that is available for querying from this database.

createdTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the database was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

lastModifiedTimestamp.documentation: The last time that the database was modified. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

KxDatabaseListEntry.documentation: Details about a FinSpace managed kdb database

deploymentStrategy.documentation:
The type of deployment that you want on a cluster.

  • ROLLING – This options updates the cluster by stopping the exiting q process and starting a new q process with updated configuration.

  • NO_RESTART – This option updates the cluster without stopping the running q process. It is only available for HDB type cluster. This option is quicker as it reduces the turn around time to update configuration on a cluster.

    With this deployment mode, you cannot update the initializationScript and commandLineArguments parameters.

KxDeploymentConfiguration.documentation: The configuration that allows you to choose how you want to update the databases on a cluster. Depending on the option you choose, you can reduce the time it takes to update the cluster.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

awsAccountId.documentation: The unique identifier of the AWS account in which you create the kdb environment.

status.documentation:
The status of the environment creation.

  • CREATE_REQUESTED – Environment creation has been requested.

  • CREATING – Environment is in the process of being created.

  • FAILED_CREATION – Environment creation has failed.

  • CREATED – Environment is successfully created and is currently active.

  • DELETE REQUESTED – Environment deletion has been requested.

  • DELETING – Environment is in the process of being deleted.

  • RETRY_DELETION – Initial environment deletion failed, system is reattempting delete.

  • DELETED – Environment has been deleted.

  • FAILED_DELETION – Environment deletion has failed.

errorMessage.documentation: Specifies the error message that appears if a flow fails.

environmentArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of your kdb environment.

kmsKeyId.documentation: The unique identifier of the KMS key.

dedicatedServiceAccountId.documentation: A unique identifier for the AWS environment infrastructure account.

transitGatewayConfiguration.documentation: Specifies the transit gateway and network configuration to connect the kdb environment to an internal network.

customDNSConfiguration.documentation: A list of DNS server name and server IP. This is used to set up Route-53 outbound resolvers.

creationTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was created in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

updateTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was modified in FinSpace. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

availabilityZoneIds.documentation: The identifier of the availability zones where subnets for the environment are created.

certificateAuthorityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the certificate authority:

availabilityZoneId.documentation: The identifier of the availability zones where subnets for the environment are created.

launchTime.documentation: The time when a particular node is started. The value is determined as epoch time in milliseconds. For example, the value for Monday, November 1, 2021 12:00:00 PM UTC is specified as 1635768000000.

KxNode.documentation: A structure that stores metadata for a kdb node.

type.documentation:
The type of writeable storage space for temporarily storing your savedown data. The valid values are:

  • SDS01 – This type represents 3000 IOPS and io2 ebs volume type.

size.documentation: The size of temporary storage in gibibytes.

KxSavedownStorageConfiguration.documentation: The size and type of temporary storage that is used to hold data during the savedown process. All the data written to this storage space is lost when the cluster node is restarted.

userArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see IAM Identifiers in the IAM User Guide.

iamRole.documentation: The IAM role ARN that is associated with the user.

createTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb user was created.

updateTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb user was updated.

KxUser.documentation: A structure that stores metadata for a kdb user.

LimitExceededException.documentation: A service limit or quota is exceeded.

nextToken.documentation: A token generated by FinSpace that specifies where to continue pagination if a previous request was truncated. To get the next set of pages, pass in the nextTokennextToken value from the response object of the previous page call.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

environments.documentation: A list of all of your FinSpace environments.

nextToken.documentation: A token that you can use in a subsequent call to retrieve the next set of results.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

kxChangesets.documentation: A list of changesets for a database.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

nodes.documentation: A list of nodes associated with the cluster.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

clusterType.documentation:
Specifies the type of KDB database that is being created. The following types are available:

  • HDB – A Historical Database. The data is only accessible with read-only permissions from one of the FinSpace managed kdb databases mounted to the cluster.

  • RDB – A Realtime Database. This type of database captures all the data from a ticker plant and stores it in memory until the end of day, after which it writes all of its data to a disk and reloads the HDB. This cluster type requires local storage for temporary storage of data during the savedown process. If you specify this field in your request, you must provide the savedownStorageConfiguration parameter.

  • GATEWAY – A gateway cluster allows you to access data across processes in kdb systems. It allows you to create your own routing logic using the initialization scripts and custom code. This type of cluster does not require a writable local storage.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.
A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

kxDatabases.documentation: A list of databases in the kdb environment.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.
A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

environments.documentation: A list of environments in an account.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in this request.

users.documentation: A list of users in a kdb environment.

nextToken.documentation: A token that indicates where a results page should begin.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name of the resource.

tags.documentation: A list of all tags for a resource.

ruleNumber.documentation: The rule number for the entry. For example 100. All the network ACL entries are processed in ascending order by rule number.

protocol.documentation: The protocol number. A value of -1 means all the protocols.

ruleAction.documentation: Indicates whether to allow or deny the traffic that matches the rule.

portRange.documentation: The range of ports the rule applies to.

icmpTypeCode.documentation: Defines the ICMP protocol that consists of the ICMP type and code.

cidrBlock.documentation: The IPv4 network range to allow or deny, in CIDR notation. For example, 172.16.0.0/24. We modify the specified CIDR block to its canonical form. For example, if you specify 100.68.0.18/18, we modify it to 100.68.0.0/18.

NetworkACLEntry.documentation: The network access control list (ACL) is an optional layer of security for your VPC that acts as a firewall for controlling traffic in and out of one or more subnets. The entry is a set of numbered ingress and egress rules that determine whether a packet should be allowed in or out of a subnet associated with the ACL. We process the entries in the ACL according to the rule numbers, in ascending order.

from.documentation: The first port in the range.

to.documentation: The last port in the range.

PortRange.documentation: The range of ports the rule applies to.

ResourceNotFoundException.documentation: One or more resources can't be found.

ServiceQuotaExceededException.documentation: You have exceeded your service quota. To perform the requested action, remove some of the relevant resources, or use Service Quotas to request a service quota increase.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the resource.

tags.documentation: One or more tags to be assigned to the resource.

ThrottlingException.documentation: The request was denied due to request throttling.

transitGatewayID.documentation: The identifier of the transit gateway created by the customer to connect outbound traffics from kdb network to your internal network.

routableCIDRSpace.documentation: The routing CIDR on behalf of kdb environment. It could be any "/26 range in the 100.64.0.0 CIDR space. After providing, it will be added to the customer's transit gateway routing table so that the traffics could be routed to kdb network.

attachmentNetworkAclConfiguration.documentation: The rules that define how you manage the outbound traffic from kdb network to your internal network.

TransitGatewayConfiguration.documentation: The structure of the transit gateway and network configuration that is used to connect the kdb environment to an internal network.

resourceArn.documentation: A FinSpace resource from which you want to remove a tag or tags. The value for this parameter is an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

tagKeys.documentation: The tag keys (names) of one or more tags to be removed.

environmentId.documentation: The identifier of the FinSpace environment.

federationMode.documentation:
Authentication mode for the environment.

  • FEDERATED - Users access FinSpace through Single Sign On (SSO) via your Identity provider.

  • LOCAL - Users access FinSpace via email and password managed within the FinSpace environment.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier of the kdb environment.

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

initializationScript.documentation: Specifies a Q program that will be run at launch of a cluster. It is a relative path within .zip file that contains the custom code, which will be loaded on the cluster. It must include the file name itself. For example, somedir/init.q.

commandLineArguments.documentation: Specifies the key-value pairs to make them available inside the cluster.

deploymentConfiguration.documentation: The configuration that allows you to choose how you want to update the code on a cluster.

environmentId.documentation: The unique identifier of a kdb environment.

clusterName.documentation: A unique name for the cluster that you want to modify.

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

databases.documentation: The structure of databases mounted on the cluster.

deploymentConfiguration.documentation: The configuration that allows you to choose how you want to update the databases on a cluster.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

transitGatewayConfiguration.documentation: Specifies the transit gateway and network configuration to connect the kdb environment to an internal network.

customDNSConfiguration.documentation: A list of DNS server name and server IP. This is used to set up Route-53 outbound resolvers.

awsAccountId.documentation: The unique identifier of the AWS account that is used to create the kdb environment.

errorMessage.documentation: Specifies the error message that appears if a flow fails.

kmsKeyId.documentation: The KMS key ID to encrypt your data in the FinSpace environment.

dedicatedServiceAccountId.documentation: A unique identifier for the AWS environment infrastructure account.

customDNSConfiguration.documentation: A list of DNS server name and server IP. This is used to set up Route-53 outbound resolvers.

creationTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was created in FinSpace.

updateTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was updated.

availabilityZoneIds.documentation: The identifier of the availability zones where subnets for the environment are created.

errorMessage.documentation: Specifies the error message that appears if a flow fails.

kmsKeyId.documentation: The KMS key ID to encrypt your data in the FinSpace environment.

dedicatedServiceAccountId.documentation: A unique identifier for the AWS environment infrastructure account.

customDNSConfiguration.documentation: A list of DNS server name and server IP. This is used to set up Route-53 outbound resolvers.

creationTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was created in FinSpace.

updateTimestamp.documentation: The timestamp at which the kdb environment was updated.

availabilityZoneIds.documentation: The identifier of the availability zones where subnets for the environment are created.

iamRole.documentation: The IAM role ARN that is associated with the user.

clientToken.documentation: A token that ensures idempotency. This token expires in 10 minutes.

userArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see IAM Identifiers in the IAM User Guide.

environmentId.documentation: A unique identifier for the kdb environment.

iamRole.documentation: The IAM role ARN that is associated with the user.

ValidationException.documentation: The input fails to satisfy the constraints specified by an AWS service.

securityGroupIds.documentation: The unique identifier of the VPC security group applied to the VPC endpoint ENI for the cluster.

subnetIds.documentation: The identifier of the subnet that the Privatelink VPC endpoint uses to connect to the cluster.

ipAddressType.documentation:
The IP address type for cluster network configuration parameters. The following type is available:

  • IP_V4 – IP address version 4

VpcConfiguration.documentation: Configuration details about the network where the Privatelink endpoint of the cluster resides.

documentation: The FinSpace management service provides the APIs for managing FinSpace environments.
